Yen Tian Yu

University of Colorado Denver · Denver, CO 80217 · (720) 255-1894 · yentyu@gmail.com

Hi! My name is Tian Yu Yen and I am a mathematician, statistician, proud father, and capoeirista-on-the-side. Through my career in mathematics, I aim to train and mentor the next generation of STEM professionals—especially, those individuals who have faced systematic and historic barriers to obtaining a career in STEM. By pursuing impactful research, demonstrating inspiring leadership, and utilizing innovative pedagogy, I work to make rigorous mathematical thinking and advanced statistical tools accessible to anyone who seeks them.

Research Vision

To collaborate with a diverse group of scientific domain experts to apply cutting-edge techniques in the fields of uncertainty quantification and machine learning to solve a broad range of consequential problems regarding inferences, inverses, prediction, and forecasting.

Current Research Goals
  • To expand the accessibility and use of data consistent inversion as a method to quantify uncertainties in physical, engineering, and biomedical models.
  • To extend Data Consistent Inversion as a method for learning statistical models.
Other Research Interests

Uncertainty quantification, Bayesian non-parametrics, density estimation, neural networks, machine learning, dimension reduction, fluid dynamics

Research Experience

Research Experience

Graduate Research Assistant

University of Colorado Denver

Advisor: Troy Butler

Details
  • Extended the theoretical and algorithmic framework for Data-Consistent Inversion to stochastic maps with applications to model discrepancy
  • Formulated and analyzed data-consistent solutions utilizing Dirichlet processes to quantify uncertainties on finite observational data
  • Contributed to BET, a measure theoretic computational package for solving inverse problems
Su. 2017, Fa. 2019, Fa. 2020

National Energy and Technology Lab (NETL)

Details

  • Created reports for the carbon capture research group on machine-learning methods and approaches for computational chemistry

University of Coloardo Denver

Advisor: Jan Mandel

Details
  • Researched flux limiters for level set methods in Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) models
  • Implemented large-scale WRF wildfire models on CU Denver clusters to simulate wildfire propagation
Fa. 2015 - Sp. 2016

Teaching Philosophy

My approach to teaching can be summarized in four statements:

I believe that there is something valuable in mathematics for everyone, regardless of their field of study, their cultural background, or their previous experiences with math. In my classes, I work to support students in finding this value and to discover how mathematical thinking applies to their own personal and/or professional lives. This requires that my approach to teaching be student-centered, focusing on the interests, needs, and abilities of the students in my classroom.

“Mathematics is for everyone,” also reflects my commitment to supporting equal access to rigorous mathematical thinking, especially for those individuals who have historically been discouraged or tracked out of advanced mathematics. To meet this commitment in my practice, I build strong relationships with students, address student concerns from a perspective of equity over equality, and create a classroom environment where every student feels like their voice is valued. In addition, outside of the classroom, I contribute my time and energy to mentor and advocate for my students.

Active learning is a broad range of teaching strategies and techniques which focus on engaging students in their own learning, including everything from strategies like think-pair-share to inquiry-based learning. Research has shown that active learning strategies increase student understanding and performance, even when some students feel like they are learning less from the experience (references). In my classroom, I provide as many opportunities as possible for students to discuss and reflect about the material they are learning.

Outside of the classroom, I have created and designed activities for a variety of mathematics curriculum from statistics to calculus to machine learning. These include activities which address different learning styles (for instance, tactile and visual activities), as well as computational demonstrations of concepts that supplement the standard curriculum. I believe that as highly-trained, professional mathematicians, we have a unique capacity and responsibility to think deeply about the mathematical structure of our curriculum and design activities that simultaneously elucidate fundamental concepts while challenging students to think deeply about the material as well.

When students feel like they belong to a community of learners, I believe that they are more likely to be motivated and successful at tackling difficult mathematics. In addition, by building community in the classroom, students will be more likely to collaborate with their peers and develop critical communication skills that are increasingly relevant for careers in any field, STEM or otherwise.

As the leader of the classroom, it is my responsibility to facilitate an inclusive community that helps all students build positive, supportive relationships. This is especially important in an environment where students may experience math anxiety or a version of imposter syndrome. In my practice, I work to create an inclusive community by investing students in making cultural norms and offering opportunities for students to start building relationships inside and outside the classroom.

In order to become masterful at an art or science, you must make mistakes. I place a great value on student mistakes as opportunities for learning. I work to create an environment where students feel comfortable making mistakes and receiving feedback, and try to give students the opportunity to grow from these experiences whenever possible. However, making mistakes is not just for students, it is important for teachers as well.

To become an inspiring teacher, I continuously challenge myself to improve my pedagogy. This means that sometimes I will try new strategies with students that are not always successful. However, just like my students, I take these opportunities to learn from these experiences and find new ways to continue to make students experience and learning in my classroom the best that it can possibly be.

Interests

Apart from my professional career as a mathematician/statistician, I am a Capoeirista, dancer, and father. I have always found that moving my body has provided clarity and stability in my life—something that I have found to be especially true while being a parent!
